Award.AwardTitle: Creating a Vision and Strategic Plan for Increasing STEM Capacity at Tohono O'odham Community College

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the research capacity at these institutions expands the opportunities for students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be locally relevant, and encourages a faculty community to look beyond the traditional classroom for intellectual and professional growth. This project aligns directly with that goal, allowing the institution?s faculty and administrators to design and develop a comprehensive plan for improving and expanding STEM instruction.


Tohono O'odham Community College will conduct an institutional assessment of its STEM programs and create a strategic plan for increasing its STEM capacity. Workshops that include TOCC faculty and administration, TOCC students, Tohono O'odham Nation departments, stakeholders and external educational institutions will formulate a shared vision of what STEM capacity should be at TOCC and how to achieve it. The results of the assessment will constitute the baseline for the elaboration of a STEM Capacity-building plan and NSF TCUP STEM Instructional Capacity Excellence proposal for 2017. The plan will include a systemic, comprehensive approach to integrating our curriculum into the Tohono O'odham way of life (Himdag) through the application of an indigenous education model. This plan will also include innovative educational strategies such as the creation of learning communities focused on integrative and problem-based learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported an extensive institutional assessment of Tohono O'odham Community College (TOCC) STEM programs and the creation of a strategic plan to strengthen and expand the college's STEM programs and to increase the participation of Tohono O'odham professionals in the STEM disciplines.  From March-June 2017 this project engaged internal and external stakeholders in an extensive planning process to identify strengths, challenges, and opportunities for STEM at TOCC, and to formulate a shared vision for future STEM programs at TOCC.  Visioning sessions were held that drew a broad representation of students, faculty, administrators, partners, agencies, and professional educators from across the southwest region, appropriately centered on the local community, allowing deep input and direction into the five-year strategic plan to support STEM at TOCC.

A total of 81 participants attended the different sessions from March through June 2017.  The visioning sessions identified challenges and opportunities regarding recruitment and retention of Tohono O'odham students in STEM fields, including means of supporting interested students who lack some of the necessary math and science skills.  The visioning sessions identified specific areas of development of current STEM programs that would make them more responsive to the interest of TOCC students and the needs of the Tohono O'odham Nation (TON). These specific areas of interest are in hands-on, place-based learning which incorporates quantitative and technical skill-building as well as Physics, Astronomy, and Engineering.  The visioning sessions laid the groundwork for future opportunities for partnerships with the TON, regional employers and external partners, including 2+2 programs, internships opportunities for students, and career pathways. The results of the visioning sessions suggested that strengthening the physical science offerings and developing a two-year Physics program was a greater priority than the development of four-year programs.  The visioning sessions affirmed the need to increase student engagement and success through expansion of integrative, problem-based learning approaches across TOCC's STEM curriculum.

This project resulted in an assessment and a design for STEM instructional improvement, which incorporates elements of self-determination and culturally based education in the context of the current generation of Tohono O'odham students.  This five-year strategic plan includes a systemic, comprehensive approach to integrating curriculum into the Tohono O'odham way of life (Himdag) through the application of an indigenous education model, the Man in the Maze Educational (MiME) Model.   The faculty development workshops supported by the grant affirmed that the faculty are receptive to and can apply this indigenous education model in their courses and programs to integrate traditional knowledge and incorporate culturally-relevant assessment.

 The final visioning workshop reviewed and prioritized the results of the stakeholder visioning sessions in conjunction with TOCC's strategic plan, institutional data and best practices in indigenous STEM education.  Four pillars for the STEM capacity building along with action items were identified and used to create a five-year strategic STEM plan.   This five-year strategic plan for STEM was used as a basis for a successful $2.5M NSF TCUP Instructional Capacity Excellence for Tribal Institutions proposal,  Pathways to Indigenous STEM (Ma:cidag wo:g STEM Wui) proposal which will support the fulfillment of the strategic plan.

The five-year strategic STEM plan incorporates unique and innovative instructional strategies that are integrated into the Tohono O'odham Himdag with the goal of preparing Tohono O'odham students to face the current and future challenges with both 21st-century knowledge and traditional knowledge.  In addition, the incorporation of the MiME model represents a significant contribution to the understanding of how to implement and assess culturally based education.
